and align yourself

1557.29.text:
so that you wind up

1559.36.text:
that has breadth and
that you can be proud of.

1563.56.text:
Striving to be normal
is a low bar anyway.

1568.27.text:
Great ideas are a waste
of the human experience

1573.94.text:
So when you don't
walk in your purpose,

1576.21.text:
when you don't nurture
and use your gifts,

1578.84.text:
then blockage manifests
inside of you,

1581.48.text:
because that energy has

1583.38.text:
and it builds up
and it shows up

1590.56.text:
Women today are going
through a great transition.

1595.36.text:
For thousands of years,
we were told

1597.63.text:
that we weren't emotionally
intelligent enough

1600.70.text:
to be a leader, but
we birthed leaders.

1604.90.text:
For thousands of years,
our pictures were removed

1607.54.text:
from the cosmos and replaced
with masculine figures.

1611.51.text:
We were conditioned to think
that we were a man's helpmate

1614.41.text:
rather than the concept
of being equally necessary

1622.15.text:
the stories have
even been removed

1624.59.text:
from our history
and our holy books.

1627.03.text:
They even hid the fact that
El Shaddai had many breasts

1630.66.text:
intended to feed
the whole world.

1634.40.text:
I've heard it said that men
are "naturally visual," heh.

1639.00.text:
But that just excuses their
inability to connect to it.

1649.25.text:
which is why we surround
them with bright colors.

1652.08.text:
And every time they encounter
something bright and shiny,

1663.23.text:
it's able to acknowledge
a bright-colored object

1665.96.text:
as bright and colored,
before reacting physically.

1670.60.text:
It knows to
investigate the object

1673.61.text:
and find out if it's
harmful or helpful.

1677.14.text:
Men are visual because society
allows them to be visual

1680.88.text:
by not requiring them to
develop the mental muscles

1684.82.text:
necessary to investigate a
connection beyond the physical.

1688.85.text:
And if he does,
he's an anomaly.

1693.76.text:
To live in an overly-represented
masculine world

1697.80.text:
is to only recognize
the physical.

1700.47.text:
To define stories
in linear terms

1705.17.text:
centered off of a
masculine standard.

1707.54.text:
It's no wonder
why so many women

1712.44.text:
We can't truly
value another women

1716.75.text:
But you-- let me
tell you, women--

1718.62.text:
you were even worthy even
before you birthed yourself

1722.69.text:
and if you want to
test out that theory,

1724.96.text:
try to read some history
and take women out of it.

1733.16.text:
I wrote a poem at the
very beginning of my book.

1736.94.text:
It's entitled "A Cut
That Won't Heal."

1740.57.text:
And it talks about how
difficult it is being a woman.

1744.21.text:
The cut that won't
heal is that split

1748.08.text:
between the lips
of her vagina,

1750.65.text:
and it's like being
born with a burden.

1753.55.text:
Older women taught us how to
be obligated over love to men.

1759.19.text:
They taught us how to take care
of everybody but ourselves.

1763.39.text:
We're even praised
for being superwomen

1765.96.text:
because we're able to put
up with so much stuff.

1769.37.text:
They call us "good women"
or "virtuous women,"

1771.90.text:
but today, I do not wear
that badge of glory

1779.51.text:
but because I don't want
to give off the impression

1782.25.text:
that it's okay to
ignore the oppression

1784.62.text:
of black women's face and
glorify us for our ability

1790.92.text:
Instead, I give my
body permission

1793.36.text:
to feel what comes
up right now.

1797.73.text:
I give my body permission to
release pain in a timely manner,

1803.74.text:
even if it makes somebody
else uncomfortable.

1806.87.text:
Religion gives us hope that
we can survive that servitude

1810.84.text:
but it would not allow us to

1824.06.text:
if we've, you know, been

1828.46.text:
We feel it with the

1830.90.text:
who undress us with their

1834.73.text:
Then, how do we go back

1839.74.text:
My first suggestion is

1842.57.text:

1844.94.text:
that you need in your life,
as a kind of mothering.

1848.01.text:

1852.08.text:
This is somebody who's
been where you are.

1856.96.text:
This is somebody whose
on your same level.

1859.29.text:
This friend-- this is not

1863.29.text:
that's why they're
on your level.

1867.93.text:
And then, you need
to find someone--

1872.04.text:
someone who looks up
to you for mentoring.

1874.41.text:
That is the
cycle of it.

1877.14.text:
I call it,
in my book,

1885.32.text:
it can be empowering
to find a mentor

1889.22.text:
That could be based off

1891.36.text:
your sexual orientation, your
profession, or your ability,

1894.86.text:
but it doesn't

1897.36.text:
It can be somebody
that you seek

1900.43.text:
but when you find a mentor,

If it's somebody that

1909.57.text:
read their biography or

1913.98.text:
Now-- and also finding

1917.55.text:

1919.65.text:
as an undergraduate student

1922.59.text:
You need to service a
support center-- or system--

1927.83.text:
Equity and Inclusion

1931.20.text:
When I worked for

1933.20.text:
I had a student to come
and tell me one day,

1935.00.text:

1939.10.text:

1943.81.text:

1945.74.text:
when you pass each other

1951.62.text:
and I mean really,

1954.32.text:
This the kind of elaborate
system of greeting

1957.26.text:
among people of color,

1960.26.text:
that are heavily rooted

1963.33.text:
that crossed over that big

1966.80.text:
And if you don't believe me,

1973.87.text:
Yeah, that's going

because you are like

And when you speak about

And remember, there

2049.21.text:

2060.32.text:

2066.36.text:

and it's going to repeat over

the more force it

resistance of the lesson

2085.65.text:

So people sit in parking lots

2099.03.text:
and they can't do

Sometimes, it's the

2135.40.text:

2138.30.text:

The air is thin

2154.99.text:

The higher you elevate, the less

2166.06.text:

2178.14.text:
because people will

2181.88.text:
You might not let

2186.32.text:
You know, that's
some of y'all.

2188.22.text:
But you might let them control

2192.62.text:

But let them have the

2199.13.text:
as they know it,

2201.20.text:
their truth may have looked

and will probably look

2205.97.text:

2208.01.text:
because we're all

2211.64.text:
Sometimes, we have

2214.21.text:
because there is someone
or several someones

2217.42.text:
that we have not forgiven,
including ourselves.

2222.69.text:
Forgiveness is like letting

2227.86.text:
and if you're spending
any kind of mental

2230.19.text:
or emotional energy
on grievances, hurts,

2234.07.text:
or negative incidences,
and you can't let go of it,

2237.54.text:
it clogs your spiritual

2240.61.text:
and it will block

2243.87.text:
So be clear-- forgiving
is not the same thing

2251.12.text:
Sometimes, you might even to
love them from a distance.

2255.32.text:
But forgiving is for
your benefit, not theirs.

2259.09.text:
You can begin by creating
a forgiveness journal.

2261.69.text:
We talked about that a
little bit this morning.

2264.76.text:
When I wrote my forgiveness
journal a few years ago,

2268.53.text:
I first started by
writing down the names

2270.33.text:
of everyone who I
thought did me wrong,

2275.37.text:
I wrote down 41 names
when I got tired.

2282.15.text:
And that last name,
that 41st name, that was me.

2287.15.text:
When you cannot forgive,
your heart turns hard.

2292.06.text:
And love cannot live
in a hard place.

2296.93.text:
and creating the
experiences we want

2299.46.text:
is being intentional
about your self-talk

2305.14.text:
Your subconscious never sleeps
and it believes what you say,

2309.11.text:
so when you tell yourself,
"Oh, my gosh, I'm so broke,"

2312.34.text:
yeah, you gonna be broke,
because you believe that.

2315.61.text:
When you say, "Oh, man,
I'm so stupid,"

2317.72.text:
well, you just might be
showing up as stupid.

2321.05.text:
So if you will believe that
you are broke or stupid,

2326.49.text:
why not tell yourself,
"I trust the process of life

2330.46.text:
"with no fear, because
I'm aware that everything

2333.13.text:
"is in divine order,
working for my benefit."

2338.77.text:
This is the kind of ritual
that's called "affirmations."

2342.54.text:
And when we say these daily,
you believe what you say.

2349.01.text:
You call it
into your life.

2350.75.text:
So when you say, "I welcome
unexpected income in my life."

2357.89.text:
You say that everyday
and see won't it comes

2360.22.text:
in some kind of
unexpected way.

2363.63.text:
Now, I encourage you-- because
this is powerful stuff--

2366.00.text:
use your power for good, because
if you start cursing people,

2368.60.text:
that's gonna come
back on you, too.

2372.44.text:
Meditation is another great

It's how you connect

2380.58.text:
It's not the same
thing as prayer.

2385.42.text:
or line of communication
with whomever you identify

2390.99.text:
Meditation is the
process of being still

2395.76.text:
so that you can
recalibrate yourself,

2398.36.text:
and so that you can
hear the direction.

2402.20.text:
The key to meditating
is breathing,

2408.71.text:
This is why women in labor
have breathing coaches

2411.98.text:
because when we work so much,
we forget to breathe.

2416.08.text:
Being conscious of your breath
allows you to appreciate

2418.85.text:
the journey rather than
focus on the labor.

2423.05.text:
Now, there's several other
ways that I recommend

2427.26.text:
that you can raise
your vibration

2430.06.text:
We talked a little bit this
morning about some of these.

2433.73.text:
I tell women all the time,
you keep sage in your house

2437.13.text:
like you would keep
salt and pepper

2438.67.text:
because it will push out

2442.61.text:
I was a child that just
turned 17, and 15 was hard.

2452.62.text:
You can even say
your affirmations,

2454.65.text:

2458.62.text:
and let that energy
be in there.

2460.66.text:
You can keep crystals

2462.73.text:

plants in your house

2465.16.text:
because they help

2467.60.text:
And they keep life

2473.20.text:
The more you clutter,
the more you're clogging

2478.34.text:
You can keep journals,
a gratitude journal,

2484.01.text:
And exercise, because your body
was not meant to be sedentary.

2490.99.text:
I recommend for people to
get massages regularly,

2500.53.text:
A lot of times, what women
do is we start out--

2505.00.text:
We start out
way down here,

2507.17.text:
and so when we get our

2510.01.text:
we barely getting back

2512.71.text:
That's not where

2515.08.text:
You want to

2516.15.text:
so that you can get

2519.48.text:
But if you're always
working in a deficit,

2522.75.text:
it's going to take away

2530.63.text:
People can put intentions
in your food, as well,

2532.86.text:
but whatever you eat
is either medicine...

2544.28.text:
Sit in nature-- in fact,
energy is the strongest

2547.68.text:
near oceans and rivers
and mountains and forests.

2550.55.text:
Just kind of sit
there and meditate.

2553.55.text:
So all of these rituals
produce energy,

2559.12.text:
So you've got to be
intentional of what energy

2561.99.text:
that you are inviting,

2567.93.text:
These rituals help you to

2572.57.text:
so they can see
what you cannot see.

2575.54.text:
And they'll also help you

2580.08.text:
and that is the space between
your mind and your heart.

2587.92.text:
In fact, sound is a
natural opener of doorways

2591.72.text:
between the physical world
and the spiritual world.

2601.83.text:
So I'm going to leave
you with a final thought

2606.80.text:
In following some
of these things,

2608.31.text:
I want you to be prepared

2610.87.text:
who claim to know you, if you

2616.68.text:

2622.82.text:
If you not changing, you
staying where you always were,

and things don't work

2638.27.text:

haven't been there in a while,

because you gotta

in order to get to the

2657.99.text:
It's a child who saw her
mother cut the edges

2660.49.text:
off of the roast before
she put it in the freezer.

2663.79.text:
And so, the child
asked her mother,

2665.80.text:
"Mama, why do you cut the edges
off the edge of the roast

2670.87.text:
"before you put it
in the freezer?"

2672.74.text:
And her mother said,
"Hmm, I don't know.

2677.78.text:
So the little girl went
and asked her grandmother.

2680.48.text:
She said grandma, "Why
you always cut the edges

2684.18.text:
"off the roast before you
put it in the freezer?"

2687.45.text:
And she said, "Oh,
chil', I don't know.

2689.65.text:
"I always did it because
my mama did it."

2692.39.text:
And so, the young girl
was very fortunate

2697.56.text:
So she went to her great
grandmother and said,

2700.33.text:
"G-mama, why you always cut
the edges off the roast

2704.13.text:
"before you put it
in the freezer?"

2705.64.text:
And she said, "Oh,
chil', that's easy.

2708.24.text:
"When I was growing up,
the freezer was so small,

2710.44.text:
"that's the only way you
could get it in there."

2717.08.text:
So the purpose of
that is to recognize

2724.35.text:
and only universal
truth remains constant.

2728.06.text:
We have to be careful what
we celebrate, protect,

2730.86.text:
and revere as cultural
or traditional

2732.83.text:
because the tradition may
no longer be applicable.

2737.30.text:
So may the prayers
of the grandmothers

2740.14.text:
invoke a discerning
spirit in you tonight

2743.27.text:
and may your
thoughts and actions

2745.21.text:
lean toward alignment
of your destiny.

Now, I was told that we're

and I think there are

if you want to

2774.54.text:
Feel free to
get in an isle.

2803.80.text:

the way in the back.

>> I just wondered if you
ever heard of the chant

2819.12.text:
Nam-myoho-renge-kyo...
>> Yes, yes, yes, yes I have.

2824.82.text:

2836.40.text:

>> I have a question for you

2852.38.text:

2863.39.text:

2867.60.text:

may want to be nasty about it

2872.90.text:
because it make
you feel better,

2874.74.text:

until you're strong enough

2881.38.text:
I've talked to many
women who would ask me

2883.85.text:
about, "I'm going back

2887.45.text:
because holidays are so hard
for them to go home to.

2894.76.text:
Why would you do
anything that is

2899.36.text:
You're putting yourself
in harm-- don't go.

2905.87.text:
But when I say "when
you're strong," remember,

2908.61.text:
many of us starting
out at a deficit.

2911.98.text:
You can't even be
at ground zero.

2914.28.text:
You need to
be up here,

2916.31.text:
so that you have some
kind of... collateral.

2920.42.text:
You go home when
you're here.

2923.35.text:
And you can call them up and

2927.76.text:
You ain't even
gotta be there.

2929.23.text:
It's cool if you can be because
I believe in the pheromones

2931.93.text:
going back and fourth--
that's real.

2935.33.text:
Because when you learn
that your mother is a woman

2940.07.text:
before she was ever a mother,
it changes your perspective.

2978.94.text:
>> My question is what
makes it so specific

2983.88.text:
about black girl pain
instead of just woman pain?

2991.15.text:

2999.76.text:

on diversity, equity,

3002.77.text:
and inclusion, specifically
for education majors

3005.84.text:
at Kennesaw State University--
I teach twice a week.

3008.74.text:
And I am passionate about
teaching this class

3012.41.text:
because 84% of the teachers
in our country

3018.68.text:
And ain't nothing wrong
with being white...

3020.68.text:
however, when just about
all of our children

3024.92.text:
are hearing this story
from one perspective,

3030.33.text:
So that's why-- that's
what motivates me

3033.10.text:
And when I get that question,
what I share with them

3036.47.text:
is that if you go back to
the slave plantation, right?

3043.74.text:
There were some white women
that were being abused.

3048.01.text:
Some of them were upset
because their husbands

3050.98.text:
were-- they called it "cheating
on them" with the slaves.

3056.65.text:
But then, you have
a slave woman, right?

3061.22.text:
She was being bred
to have more children

3064.26.text:
that sometimes she
couldn't keep, right?

3069.30.text:
And if she thought she was
going to love a person,

3075.07.text:
the Master would come and ruin
all of that by raping her.

3079.78.text:
So we have two different
experiences of women--

3085.55.text:
So yes, while they both
have very similar themes,

3090.59.text:
the experience is
often not the same,

3093.66.text:
so let's fast-forward a little
bit to suffrage, right?

3098.33.text:
Black men actually got the right
to vote before white women,

3102.47.text:
as if there really should have
been some kind of competition.

3105.64.text:
However, when black men
got the right to vote,

3110.07.text:
black women would not vote
because she was a woman.

3114.34.text:
When white-- if white women
hadn't got the chance

3118.08.text:
black women still would
not have been able to vote

3122.45.text:
So let's move up now
to the '60s and '70s.

3124.55.text:
We're talking about
the women's movement,

3128.63.text:
where you had white women
who were sitting at home,

3132.30.text:
wanting to go to work
and wanting fair pay,

3136.50.text:
but you had women of color who
have been working for free

3145.58.text:
When you talk about
intergenerational trauma,

3151.18.text:
but it doesn't mean you
experience it the same.

3154.92.text:
If you have not
heard this term,

3157.09.text:
I highly recommend
you look up

3158.66.text:
"Post Traumatic Slave
Syndrome" by Dr. Joy DeGruy.

3163.59.text:
And that will
explain all of that

3165.83.text:
and how slavery still
impacts us today.

3169.13.text:
And it doesn't just
impact black people.

3171.13.text:
It impacts white
people, too, right?

3173.60.text:
Just-- it-- we experience
it differently.

3177.51.text:
For some white people,
what it did for them

3180.21.text:
is make them lose
their humanity.

3183.35.text:
How can you go to
church as a Christian,

3191.25.text:
and then go and lynch a person
in the afternoon, right?

3196.63.text:
What does that do
to you, cognitively?

3203.13.text:
so what we do with
cognitive dissonance

3204.97.text:
is we either rename,
relabel, or redefine

3209.07.text:
what we're doing or
who we're doing it to

3211.21.text:
in order to make you
comfortable with doing it.

3214.24.text:
So we said that they
weren't even people.

3219.42.text:
We still have the
electoral college.

3220.82.text:
That had everything
to do with slavery.

3225.79.text:
but slaves being counted
as three-fifths of a person.

3231.73.text:
where else do we
have an election

3236.83.text:
where it is not
the popular vote?

3238.97.text:
Why do we need somebody
to vote for us today?

3241.54.text:
It doesn't happen
any place else.

3244.51.text:
Did I answer your question?
>> Thank you.

3274.34.text:
My question for you is how do
we as men, we as black men,

3289.12.text:
>> I am not a man, so I
can't tell you what to do.

3292.46.text:
And I'm being my
authentic self,

3293.69.text:
so when I even have--
sometimes, white people ask me,

3303.57.text:
"and don't rely on me to
tell you what that is."

3306.04.text:
That's one-- now,
there are some steps.

3308.14.text:
First of all, you need
to heal yourself, right?

3313.38.text:
because-- and this
is for anybody--

3315.91.text:
before you can understand
how you relate to the world,

3320.55.text:
you gotta understand
who you are.

3323.05.text:
So if you don't
understand that,

3324.55.text:
you'll never be able
to mistreat them.

3326.82.text:
You know, I'm
clear about this.

3329.66.text:
Whatever privilege you have,
whether it's male privilege,

3332.40.text:
whether it's white privilege,
whatever privilege you have,

3335.83.text:
I don't think it should be
anything that you're ashamed of

3344.67.text:
What are you doing
with that privilege

3346.84.text:
to help leverage equity
for other people?

3349.11.text:
So young man, when you see
another woman being mistreated

3355.22.text:
Even if it's not going
to do any good for you,

3362.29.text:
You know, I think silence puts
you on the side of the oppressor

3369.87.text:
>> Thank you.
>> You are quite welcome.

3376.94.text:
I just wanted you to
elaborate a little bit

3378.81.text:
on how religion enslaved us
and saved us at the same time.

3389.42.text:
it saved us a few
different ways.

3395.29.text:
if we did not convert
to Christianity,

3400.16.text:
That was one way
it saved us.

3403.17.text:
Another way that
it helped save us

3405.10.text:
is that when you look at
the spiritual practices

3415.65.text:
but what they did was they
hid them in Christianity,

3420.28.text:
and we even practice a lot of
them today without context.

3425.09.text:
You go to the Caribbean,
you go to Cuba,

3427.16.text:
you go to South America,
the black folks there,

3430.89.text:
they black because you
know those cruise ships,

3433.16.text:
they landed a few
different places.

3439.54.text:
So to stay alive, and still
connect with their ancestors

3447.94.text:
inside of one of
the Catholic deities.

3450.48.text:
So when they got white folks
thinking they praying

3453.58.text:
to Saint Barbara, they
really praying to Oshun.

3460.86.text:
So when you look at
even some of the rituals

3463.66.text:
you won't see it unless
you know what to look for,

3465.36.text:
but this is something
that I've been reading

3467.46.text:
and studying lately, and
I think it's my next book...

3471.10.text:
is how to locate those
things in our churches

3474.14.text:
and in our ways
of being.

3477.91.text:
because they ain't
killing us anymore with it,

3480.68.text:
but it had to change
over time, you know?

3485.11.text:
So because we had to change it
in order for it to survive.

3488.22.text:
So that's one way
that it saved us.

3491.55.text:
Some of us forgot
the context

3494.02.text:
and really believed the
inferiority that it taught us.

3501.60.text:
When you go to
black churches,

3505.90.text:
it's real big to be pastor,
reverend doctor, right?

3509.41.text:
Those titles were huge
because, in society,

3513.68.text:
you weren't going to get
no title except for "boy."

3527.06.text:
>> Thank you to
Dr. Consuela Ward
